ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This is a spectacular course. Alark Saxena is a fabulous discussion leader, and very insightful. The structure of the course was great. The first half was a lot of academic background material, and we had lecture/seminar discussion much of the time. The second half of the course were student led discussions on various topics that applied the theoretical work from the first half of the course. Every one of the student presentations was excellent, which reflects how highly engaged all of the students were in the course. There were also guest lecturers most weeks, and they were all very interesting and provided additional perspectives on the issues in the course.
Though there were no field trips, the presentations by such a wide array of practitioners, professionals and persons for Academia made this component unnecessary.

Overall very good course and great discussions. Some guest speakers were a bit lacking. Too many readings with overlap that did not always fit together and were dense - place to improve the course is with the readings. Final presentations were rushed, spreading them out and allowing an addition 3 minutes would be better. A debate format for an assignment would be good and this is a comment for may of my classes as this is something lacking at FES and would require criticisms from students on theory or practices to propose alternatives or argue their view rather than just critiques.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: See response to question 13

The in-class dialogue. The encouragement from the professor to hear many many different views. The ability of the professor to quickly analyze what was said, relate it to theory, current practical international and national experiences while balancing views with the offering of a different perspective. Excellent!!!

I really enjoyed the readings for the course. Alark is also very enthusiastic and passionate about this topic; meeting with him for my group's presentation and for my final paper was immensely helpful.
The weekly guest lecturer who had a strong understanding of Resilience and provided us an opportunity to network.
I think that the balance of conceptual and applied material was excellent. I loved complementing the lectures with guest speakers
discussions.
I got to learn a lot from the different guest lectures that were invited in person, though Skype which was quite cool.
Guest speakers and Alark's lectures

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The volume of reading in the first half of the course was a little too heavy - more that one could effectively do with a normal course load.

No more weakly responses of so so so many papers. perhaps a response to one paper if it must be a weekly Friday response. I would have liked to see the theory be more deeply discussed and well understood by all class participants before moving forward.

Number 1 concern with the course = not enough time for discussion. Discussion was by far the richest part of the course and there was never enough time. Ideal breakdown would be 1.5 hours lecture, 1.5 hours discussion. Too many readings - I only did the ones that were labeled "mandatory." Optional readings I could not get to. Need more time on the theory and more a more explicit connection between theory and the case studies. Sometime I felt like the link there was missing. Would be interesting to get more U.S. examples, as there are many vulnerable/at-risk communities here where resilience is a challenge. Rather than writing a memo, it would be helpful to assign a first draft of the paper. If the memo needs to stay, it would be good to assign a better structure. I had never written anything like it before and felt a bit lost. But really I think the memo could be scrapped in place of a draft; it'd have been helpful to get Alark's feedback and would have been useful for pacing throughout the semester.
The discussion forum gets too cluttered I feel and we may need more time to respond.
I think this was part of the point, but sometimes it felt like we were just swimming in the conceptual material and I wasn't sure what we were supposed to take away.
readings and assignments. reading responses took a lot of time but could have been varied from week to week such as more memos or other variations.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
Very very effective! Propelled great discussions. Maybe ask shy people also what they thought. Sometimes the domineering folks took over.
NA

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: the subject of resilience interests me. But I took the course because of who the instructor is.
Perfectly aligned with the work I am doing on building and supporting resilience in SIDS and International marine policy.

This was the ONLY course explicitly taught around resilience and adaptation at FES this year. Very grateful to Alark for bringing this topic to the fore! Resilience directly connects to my interest in climate change adaptation. There needs to be more of this at FES!
Fits very well, especially given the developing world context. I think there should be more courses like this offered.
This course helps to flesh out my current understanding of cutting-edge environmental thinking. It was great to gain a better sense of truly interdisciplinary environmental work, too.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because the instructor is fantastic
I took it because it is perfectly aligned with what I am and will be doing. Wanted to learn more. After the first class I knew it would be a perfect fit.
100% related to my academic/professional interests. Also was excited to take a course with Alark, who I heard many good things about!
For the developing world context.
I took this course because it sounded like an exciting introduction to a topic that has sort of taken on a meaning of its own.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes.
Yes; just was a bit disappointed by the limited discussion.
Yes! It was a very thorough introduction to, and exploration of, the many meanings of "resilience."

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Presentation Group - I got to learn from my group mates as well as share what I knew. Final Project Group - I also had the opportunity to research more based on questions that we both came up with. It forced us to dig deeper and challenged us to produce an item of quality that would be desirable.
My group worked together on our presentation with a lot of success. We were a good time and all worked cohesively and effectively.
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Don't miss out on the opportunity to take this course

Worth the effort!!! TAKE IT !!!!! you learn so much that can be applied in the field! Great complementary course to Amy Vedders Toolkit. Try not to do both in the same semester. You may not survive :D unless of course you add 2 very light courses.

Take this course! It's a great intro to resilience and really serves as an important critique of everything we are used to seeing in the adaptation sector. Alark is a passionate and invested prof, and you will definitely learn a lot!
It's an important course even if you don't plan to work in the developing world, it'll provide you with a frame of mind for what needs to be done there.
The course can be a lot of work, but you will get out of it as much as you put into it.
Take it
